'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is a [[understanding|sense]] of [[behavior]]al conduct that differentiates intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are good (or right) and bad (or wrong). A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (for example, according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality, while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>
+
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is a [[understanding|sense]] of [[behavior]]al conduct that differentiates intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are good (or right) and bad (or wrong). A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (for example, according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality, while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.
  +

According to the [[Oxford English Dictionary]], the word ''morals'' was first used by [[Pope Gregory the Great]] in his work ''Morality in the Book of Job''
  +
<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/moral?region=us#m_en_us1269168.006 | title = moral | accessdate = 2011-08-14 | work = OxfordDictionaries.com}}.
  +
</ref> ''Ethics'', on the other hand, are traditionally divided into Aristotelian, Kantian and utilitarian schools. <ref>{{Cite web| url = http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/ethics?region=us | title = moral | accessdate = 2011-08-14 | work = OxfordDictionaries.com}}.</ref> Thus, we can categorize ''morals'' as a code of behaviour which comes from some source of divine revelation, while ''[[ethics]]'' is derived from human or social law or custom.
  +
